prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TW Hya: NO and CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This goal targets the Band 7 transitions of NO and CN for TW Hya.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested spectral resolution is sufficent to resolve 1 km/s lines, the typical linewidth for spectral lines in protoplanetary disks.

The angular resolution of 1'' gives us sufficient flux density to detect NO with a feasable integration time. The CO gas disk in TW Hya is roughly 7''.2 across, setting the largest angular scale. Our resolution allows us resolve the disk and distiguish between the inner and outter disk.

The detection of NO drives the sensitivity requirements for this spectral setup. Our models of the NO J = 7/2 - 5/2 emission in TW Hya predict the strongest line will have a peak flux density of 15.30 mJy for a 1'' beam. A three sigma detection requires an rms of 5.10 mJy. If the line is weaker than predicted we can improve the signal to noise by a factor of square root 3 via stacking of the three NO lines in spectral window. The peak expected line flux is 51.9 mJy for the brightest CN line. The continuum flux density is adapted from the flux density at 358 GHz as reported by Qi et al. (2013). The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TW Hya: HCN Isotopes
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This goal targets the Band 6 transitions of H13CN and HC15N as well as HNO and NO for TW Hya.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested spectral resolution is sufficent to resolve 1 km/s lines, the typical linewidth for spectral lines in protoplanetary disks.

The angular resolution of 1''.5 gives us sufficient flux density to detect H13CN at the 6 sigma level with a short integration time. The CO gas disk in TW Hya is roughly 7''.2 across, setting the largest angular scale. Our resolution allows us to resolve the disk and distiguish between the inner and outter disk.

Our models predict a peak H13CN 3-2 flux of 74.7 mJy/beam for a 1''.5 beam. The requested rms allows us to detect the line at the 6 sigma level. The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: DM Tau: NO and CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This goal targets the Band 7 transitions of NO and CN for DM Tau.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested spectral resolution is sufficent to resolve 1 km/s lines, the typical linewidth for spectral lines in protoplanetary disks.

The angular resolution of 0''.4 gives us sufficient flux density to detect NO with a reasonable, hours instead of days, integration time while maintaing the ~55 AU resolution of the TW Hya observation. The requested largest angular scale is based on the most extended CN 2-1 emission observed for this source.

The detection of NO drives the sensitivity requirements for this spectral setup. Our models of the NO J = 7/2 - 5/2 emission in TW Hya predict the strongest line will have a peak flux density of 15.30 mJy for a 0''.4 beam when scaled to the distance of DM Tau. A three sigma detection requires an rms of 5.10 mJy. If the line is weaker than predicted we can improve the signal to noise by a factor of square root 3 by stacking the three NO lines in spectral window. The peak expected line flux is 51.9 mJy for the brightest CN line. The continuum flux density is based on continuum measurements at 1.3 mm, scaled to our frequency and beam size. The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: DM Tau: HCN Isotopes
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This goal targets the Band 6 transitions of H13CN and HC15N as well as HNO and NO for DM Tau.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested spectral resolution is sufficent to resolve 1 km/s lines, the typical linewidth for spectral lines in protoplanetary disks.

The angular resolution of 0''.589 gives us sufficient flux density to detect H13CN at the 6 sigma level with a short integration time while maintaing the ~83 AU resolution of the TW Hya observation. The requested largest angular scale is based on the most extended H12CN 3-2 emission observed for this source.

Our models predict a peak H13CN 3-2 flux of 74.7 mJy/beam for a 0''.589 beam when scaled to the distance of DM Tau. The requested rms allows us to detect the line at the 6 sigma level. The requested bandwidth allows us to spectraly relove the lines and place 6 NO lines in a single spectral window. The continuum flux density is based on continuum measurements at 1.3 mm, scaled to our frequency and beam size. The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: DM Tau: N2H+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This goal targets the N2H+ 3-2 transition in Band 7 as well as DCN for DM Tau.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested spectral resolution is sufficent to resolve 1 km/s lines, the typical linewidth for spectral lines in protoplanetary disks.

At 0''.4 resolution, comperable to that requested for NO and H13CN for this source, a 3 sigma detection would take 22 hours. We have scaled back the requested resolution to 1'', which allows us to obtain a 5 sigma detection in 1.11 hours while still providing sufficient resolution to resolve the N2H+ emission, which extends over roughly 6'', setting the largest angular scale (Oberg et al. 2010).

The peak flux density of 26.9 mJy is taken from the N2H+ 3-2 detection in DM Tau by Oberg et al. (2010) and scaled to our beam size. The request rms gives us a 5 sigma detection of N2H+ 3-2. The continuum flux density is based on continuum measurements at 1.3 mm, scaled to our frequency and beam size. The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: There has been much recent work to determine the most abundant oxygen and carbon bearing molecules in protoplantary disk. However, the partitioning of nitrogen in disks is still largely unknown. This is of particular interest becasue nitrogen is important for the formation of organics. However, many solar systems bodies, including comets, are nitrogen poor. How easily nitrogen is able to be incorportated into planets depends on the dominant nitrogen bearing specis in the parent disk. We will characterize the nitrogen content in two T Tauri disks using observations of HCN isotopes, CN, and N2H+ in conjunction with a deep search for NO in a protoplanetary disk. These data, combined with our analysis, will radially map the abundances of nitrogen bearing species in the disk and constrain the presence/absence of hidden molecular nitrogen.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
